newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: DBS Bank reorganises Indonesia units.
newsitem.headline: DBS Bank reorganises Indonesia units.

text.p: The Development Bank of Singapore Ltd (DBS) said on Friday it was reorganising its holdings in the Indonesian banking sector,

It said in a statement it had entered a conditional agreement with the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd, to buy an 85 pct stake in PT Mitsubishi Buana Bank (MBB) for a cash sum of 131.75 billion rupiah (about Singapore $79 million).
DBS Bank also said it had agreed to sell its 42.5 percent shareholding in PT DBS Buana Tat Lee Bank (DBT) to Tat Lee Bank for 78.45 billion rupiah (about S$47 million).

DBS president and chief operating officer Ng Kee Choe said in a statement: "With our proposed acquisition of 85 percent and control of PT Mitsubishi Buana Bank, we have decided to divest our stake in DBT to Tat Lee Bank."
"We are now better positioned to further expand our banking operations in Indonesia through MBB, in which we will have controlling interest and will manage," Ng said.
"We will widen the scope of our activities, offer more services and expand the branch network beyond Jakarta and Surabaya to other cities in Indonesia," he said.
After DBS' acquisition of 85 percent of MBB, PT Bank Buana Indonesia would retain its original 15 percent equity stake.
The DBS statement said approvals from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Bank Indonesia and the Ministry of Finance of Indonesia had been obtained for DBS Bank's acquisition of MBB.
It said the purchase of MBB would be funded by internal resources.
The proposed transaction will not have a material impact on the consolidated net tangible assets or earnings per share of the DBS group for the financial year ending December 31, 1997.
As a result of the acquisition in DBT, Tat Lee will hold an 85 percent stake.
Ng said at a news briefing DBS was planning to expand the activities of MBB with the addition of four more branches across Indonesia.
"We don't have any time frame yet and a lot will depend on how long we take to get our staff prepared for the expansion."
Ng also said the opportunity to buy into MBB resulted from the merger of Bank of Tokyo and Mitsubishi Bank.
An official from Tat Lee Bank said the rearrangement of assets in Indonesia was of mutual benefit to both banks.
